summary_text:
Early Modern & Gondarine
Period
Early Modern Period (15th-17th Century)
• Key Rulers:
- Zara Yaqob (1434-14680012_DATE__-1468): Centralized authority, reformed the
church, and promoted education.
 Gondarine Period (1632-17690005_DATE__-1769)
• Overview: A period of stability and cultural flourishing centered in the
new capital, Gondar.
• Key Rulers:
- Fasilides: Founded Gondar, built the Fasil Ghebbi, and restored
Orthodoxy.
 I (The Great): Peak of Gondarine power, known for his
administrative reforms and patronage of the arts.
- Empress Mentewab: A powerful regent who influenced politics
and art.
• Monuments:
- Fasil Ghebbi (Royal Enclosure): A complex of castles, palaces,
and churches (e.g., Fasilides' Castle, Iyasu's Palace).
- Fasilides' Bath: A sunken pool used for Timkat (Epiphany) cele-
brations.
- Debre Berhan Selassie Church: Famous for its ceiling painted
with winged cherubs.
• Government Structure:
- Permanent Capital: Shift from mobile camps to a fixed urban
center.
- Court Etiquette: Elaborate rituals and a structured bureaucracy.
• Culture: "Gondarine Style" in art and architecture, blending Ethiopian,
Indian, and European influences.
-- Page 2 --
Era of Princes (Zemene Mesafint) (1769-18550001_DATE__-1855)
• Overview:
A period of political fragmentation where regional lords
(Rases) held power, and the Emperor was a figurehead in Gondar.
• Government Structure:
- Decentralization:
Power shifted to regional centers like Tigray,
Wollo, and Gojjam.
- Puppet Emperors: The Solomonic line continued but without real
authority.
